"**(Sittin ' On) The Dock of the Bay**" is a song co-written by
[soul](/wiki/Soul_music "Soul music") singer [Otis Redding](/wiki/Otis_Redding
"Otis Redding") and guitarist [Steve Cropper](/wiki/Steve_Cropper "Steve
Cropper"). It was recorded by Redding twice in 1967, including once just days
before his death in a plane crash. The song was released on [Stax
Records](/wiki/Stax_Records "Stax Records")' Volt label in 1968,[2] becoming
the first posthumous single to top the charts in the US.[3] It reached number
3 on the [UK Singles Chart](/wiki/UK_Singles_Chart "UK Singles Chart").

Redding started writing the lyrics to the song in August 1967, while sitting
on a rented houseboat in [Sausalito, California](/wiki/Sausalito,_California
"Sausalito, California"). He completed the song with the help of Cropper, who
was a Stax producer and the guitarist for [Booker T. & the
M.G.'s](/wiki/Booker_T._%26_the_M.G.%27s "Booker T. & the M.G.'s"). The song
features whistling and sounds of waves crashing on a shore.

##
Origins[[edit](/w/index.php?title=\(Sittin%27_On\)_The_Dock_of_the_Bay&action=edit&section=1
"Edit section: Origins")]

While on tour with [the Bar-Kays](/wiki/The_Bar-Kays "The Bar-Kays") in August
1967, Redding wrote the first verse of the song, under the abbreviated title
"Dock of the Bay," on a houseboat at Waldo Point in
[Sausalito](/wiki/Sausalito,_California "Sausalito, California"),
[California](/wiki/California "California").[1] He had completed his famed
performance at the [Monterey Pop Festival](/wiki/Monterey_Pop_Festival
"Monterey Pop Festival") just weeks earlier. While touring in support of the
albums _[King& Queen](/wiki/King_%26_Queen "King & Queen")_ (a collaboration
with female vocalist [Carla Thomas](/wiki/Carla_Thomas "Carla Thomas")) and
_[Live in Europe](/wiki/Live_in_Europe_\(Otis_Redding_album\) "Live in Europe
\(Otis Redding album\)")_ , he continued to scribble lines of the song on
napkins and hotel paper. In November of that year, he joined producer and
guitarist [Steve Cropper](/wiki/Steve_Cropper "Steve Cropper") at the Stax
recording studio in [Memphis, Tennessee](/wiki/Memphis,_Tennessee "Memphis,
Tennessee"), to record the song.[4]

In a September 1990 interview on [NPR](/wiki/NPR "NPR")'s _[Fresh
Air](/wiki/Fresh_Air "Fresh Air")_ , Cropper explained the origins of the
song:

> Otis was one of those the kind of guy who had 100 ideas. [...] He had been
> in San Francisco doing [The Fillmore](/wiki/The_Fillmore "The Fillmore").
> And the story that I got he was renting boathouse or stayed at a boathouse
> or something and that's where he got the idea of the ships coming in the bay
> there. And that's about all he had: "I watch the ships come in and I watch
> them roll away again." I just took that... and I finished the lyrics. If you
> listen to the songs I collaborated with Otis, most of the lyrics are about
> him. [...] Otis didn't really write about himself but I did. Songs like
> "[Mr. Pitiful](/wiki/Mr._Pitiful "Mr. Pitiful")," "Fa-Fa-Fa-Fa-Fa (Sad
> Song)"; they were about Otis and Otis' life. "Dock of the Bay" was exactly
> that: "I left my home in Georgia, headed for the Frisco Bay" was all about
> him going out to San Francisco to perform.[5]

Together, they completed the music and melancholy lyrics of "(Sittin' On) The
Dock of the Bay." From those sessions emerged Redding's final recorded work,
including "Dock of the Bay," which was recorded on November 22, with
additional [overdubs](/wiki/Overdub "Overdub") on December 7.[1] Redding's
restrained yet emotive delivery is backed by Cropper's memorably succinct
guitar playing.[6] The song is somewhat different in style from most of
Redding's other recordings.[1] While discussing the song with his wife,
Redding stated that he had wanted to "be a little different" with "The Dock of
the Bay" and "change his style".[1] There were concerns that "The Dock of the
Bay" had too much of a pop feel for an Otis Redding record, and contracting
the Stax [gospel](/wiki/Gospel_music "Gospel music") act the [Staple
Singers](/wiki/The_Staple_Singers "The Staple Singers") to record backing
vocals was discussed but never carried out.[1] Redding had considered the song
to be unfinished and planned to record what he considered a final version, but
never got the chance.[7] The song features a whistled tune heard before the
song's fade. It was originally performed by Redding, who (according to
Cropper) had "this little fadeout rap he was gonna do, an ad-lib. He forgot
what it was so he started whistling."[8] Redding continued to tour after the
recording sessions. On December 10, his charter plane crashed into [Lake
Monona](/wiki/Lake_Monona "Lake Monona"), outside [Madison,
Wisconsin](/wiki/Madison,_Wisconsin "Madison, Wisconsin"). Redding and six
others were killed.[9]

After Redding's death, Cropper mixed "Dock of the Bay" at Stax Studios. He
added the sound of [seagulls](/wiki/Seagulls "Seagulls") and waves crashing to
the background, as Redding had requested, recalling the sounds he heard when
he was staying on the houseboat.[10] The fade-out whistling was originally
recorded by Redding and was re-recorded by his bandleader, [Sam "Bluzman"
Taylor](/wiki/Sam_Taylor_\(blues_musician\) "Sam Taylor \(blues
musician\)").[11][12]

"The Dock of the Bay" has been hugely popular, even after its stay at the top
of the charts. The song has been recorded by many artists, from Redding's
peers, like [Glen Campbell](/wiki/Glen_Campbell "Glen Campbell"),
[Cher](/wiki/Cher "Cher"), [Peggy Lee](/wiki/Peggy_Lee "Peggy Lee"), [David
Allan Coe](/wiki/David_Allan_Coe "David Allan Coe"),[19] [Bob
Dylan](/wiki/Bob_Dylan "Bob Dylan"), [Don Partridge](/wiki/Don_Partridge "Don
Partridge"),[20] [Percy Sledge](/wiki/Percy_Sledge "Percy Sledge"), [Dee
Clark](/wiki/Dee_Clark "Dee Clark"), and [Sam & Dave](/wiki/Sam_%26_Dave "Sam
& Dave"), to artists in various genres, including [Jimmy
Velvit](/wiki/Jimmy_Velvit "Jimmy Velvit") (whose cover version was included
on his 2001 [Grammy](/wiki/Grammy "Grammy")-nominated album _Sun Sea & Sand_),
[Widespread Panic](/wiki/Widespread_Panic "Widespread Panic") (who opened
their New Year's Eve 2005 concert with the song), [Waylon
Jennings](/wiki/Waylon_Jennings "Waylon Jennings") and [Willie
Nelson](/wiki/Willie_Nelson "Willie Nelson") (whose duet peaked at number 13
on the U.S. [Hot Country Songs](/wiki/Hot_Country_Songs "Hot Country Songs")
chart), [Kenny Rankin](/wiki/Kenny_Rankin "Kenny Rankin"), [Dennis
Brown](/wiki/Dennis_Brown "Dennis Brown"), [Michel
Pagliaro](/wiki/Michel_Pagliaro "Michel Pagliaro"), [Jacob
Miller](/wiki/Jacob_Miller_\(musician\) "Jacob Miller \(musician\)"), [Pearl
Jam](/wiki/Pearl_Jam "Pearl Jam"), the [Format](/wiki/The_Format "The
Format"), [T. Rex](/wiki/T._Rex_\(band\) "T. Rex \(band\)") (as the
[B-side](/wiki/A-side_and_B-side "A-side and B-side") of "Dreamy Lady",
released in 1975), [Brent Smith](/wiki/Brent_Smith "Brent Smith") of
[Shinedown](/wiki/Shinedown "Shinedown") (during an acoustic set in 2008 and
with [Zach Myers](/wiki/Zach_Myers "Zach Myers") in a [2014
EP](/wiki/Acoustic_Sessions_\(Shinedown_EP\) "Acoustic Sessions \(Shinedown
EP\)")), [Justin Nozuka](/wiki/Justin_Nozuka "Justin Nozuka") (2007), [Sara
Bareilles](/wiki/Sara_Bareilles "Sara Bareilles") (2008), and [Garth
Brooks](/wiki/Garth_Brooks "Garth Brooks") (for the 2013 _Blue-Eyed Soul_
album in the _[Blame It All on My Roots: Five Decades of
Influences](/wiki/Blame_It_All_on_My_Roots:_Five_Decades_of_Influences "Blame
It All on My Roots: Five Decades of Influences")_ compilation). [Playing for
Change](/wiki/Playing_for_Change "Playing for Change") recorded a version
featuring [Grandpa Elliott](/wiki/Grandpa_Elliott "Grandpa Elliott") and other
performers.

[Sammy Hagar](/wiki/Sammy_Hagar "Sammy Hagar") released a version of the song
as a non-album single in 1979. His version features the song's co-writer,
[Steve Cropper](/wiki/Steve_Cropper "Steve Cropper"), on guitar and members of
the band [Boston](/wiki/Boston_\(band\) "Boston \(band\)")—[Brad
Delp](/wiki/Brad_Delp "Brad Delp"), [Sib Hashian](/wiki/Sib_Hashian "Sib
Hashian") and [Barry Goudreau](/wiki/Barry_Goudreau "Barry Goudreau")—on
backup vocals.[21] Producer [John S. Carter](/wiki/Carter_\(music\) "Carter
\(music\)") had the track recorded in May 1979 with Cropper, bassist [Leland
Sklar](/wiki/Leland_Sklar "Leland Sklar") and drummer Alvin Taylor. Later, he
added Hagar's vocals with background harmonies by the three members of Boston,
with whom Hagar had just toured.[22] Although the single was a modest hit for
Hagar, peaking at number 65 on the [_Billboard_ Hot
100](/wiki/Billboard_Hot_100 "Billboard Hot 100"), he considered it Carter's
efforts to manufacture a pop top 40 pop hit despite Hagar's heavy metal
roots.[21] Hagar and Cropper's work on the song was rated the thirty-seventh
worst guitar solo in history by _[Pitchfork](/wiki/Pitchfork_\(website\)
"Pitchfork \(website\)")_ in 1998.[23] The song was not released on an album
until 1992, when it appeared on _[The Best of Sammy
Hagar](/wiki/The_Best_of_Sammy_Hagar_\(1992_album\) "The Best of Sammy Hagar
\(1992 album\)")_. The [B-side](/wiki/A-side_and_B-side "A-side and B-side")
of Hagar's single was the first release of his studio version of "[I've Done
Everything for You](/wiki/I%27ve_Done_Everything_for_You "I've Done Everything
for You")".

[Michael Bolton](/wiki/Michael_Bolton "Michael Bolton") included the song on
his 1987 album _[The Hunger](/wiki/The_Hunger_\(Michael_Bolton_album\) "The
Hunger \(Michael Bolton album\)")_. His version peaked at number 11 on the
_Billboard_ Hot 100. Zelma Redding, Otis's widow, said she was so moved by
Bolton's performance "that it brought tears to my eyes. It reminded me so much
of my husband that I know if he heard it, he would feel the same."[24] In a
framed letter that hangs on the wall of Bolton's office, she referred to the
record as "my all-time favorite version of my husband's classic."[25]

In April 2013, [Justin Timberlake](/wiki/Justin_Timberlake "Justin
Timberlake") performed the song as part of a tribute to Memphis soul music at
the "In Performance" concert series performed at the [White
House](/wiki/The_White_House "The White House"). The series was attended by
President [Barack Obama](/wiki/Barack_Obama "Barack Obama") and [First
Lady](/wiki/First_Lady "First Lady") [Michelle Obama](/wiki/Michelle_Obama
"Michelle Obama").[26]

##
Reception[[edit](/w/index.php?title=\(Sittin%27_On\)_The_Dock_of_the_Bay&action=edit&section=6
"Edit section: Reception")]

Many who first heard the final version had doubts about the song, the sound,
and the production. Among the skeptics were [Phil Walden](/wiki/Phil_Walden
"Phil Walden") and [Jim Stewart](/wiki/Jim_Stewart_\(music\) "Jim Stewart
\(music\)"). Redding accepted some of the criticisms and fine-tuned the song.
He reversed the opening, which was Redding's whistling part, and put it at the
end as suggested.[_[citation needed](/wiki/Wikipedia:Citation_needed
"Wikipedia:Citation needed")_] "The Dock of the Bay" was released early in
1968 and topped the charts in the US and UK. _Billboard_ ranked the record as
the [number 4 song for 1968](/wiki/Billboard_Year-End_Hot_100_singles_of_1968
"Billboard Year-End Hot 100 singles of 1968").

### Universal
success[[edit](/w/index.php?title=\(Sittin%27_On\)_The_Dock_of_the_Bay&action=edit&section=7
"Edit section: Universal success")]

"(Sittin' On) The Dock of the Bay" was released in January 1968, shortly after
Redding's death. [R&B](/wiki/Rhythm_and_blues "Rhythm and blues") stations
quickly added the song to their playlists, which had been saturated with
Redding's previous hits. The song shot to number one on the R&B charts in
early 1968 and, starting in March, topped the pop charts for four weeks.[27]
The album, which shared the song's title, became his largest-selling to date,
peaking at number four on the pop albums chart.[15] "Dock of the Bay" was
popular in countries across the world and became Redding's most successful
record, selling more than four million copies worldwide.[28][29] The song went
on to win two [Grammy Awards](/wiki/Grammy_Awards "Grammy Awards"): [Best R&B
Song](/wiki/Grammy_Award_for_Best_R%26B_Song "Grammy Award for Best R&B Song")
and [Best Male R&B Vocal
Performance](/wiki/Grammy_Award_for_Best_Male_R%26B_Vocal_Performance "Grammy
Award for Best Male R&B Vocal Performance").[30]

###
Legacy[[edit](/w/index.php?title=\(Sittin%27_On\)_The_Dock_of_the_Bay&action=edit&section=8
"Edit section: Legacy")]

Redding's body of work at the time of his death was immense, including a
backlog of archived recordings as well as those created in November and
December 1967, just before his death. In mid-1968, Stax Records severed its
distribution contract with [Atlantic Records](/wiki/Atlantic_Records "Atlantic
Records"), which retained the label's back catalog and the rights to the
unreleased Otis Redding masters.[31] Through its [Atco](/wiki/Atco_Records
"Atco Records") subsidiary (Atco had distributed Otis Redding's releases from
Stax's Volt label), Atlantic issued three more albums of new Redding material,
one live album, and eight singles between 1968 and 1970.[31] [Reprise
Records](/wiki/Reprise_Records "Reprise Records") issued a [live
album](/wiki/Historic_Performances_Recorded_at_the_Monterey_International_Pop_Festival
"Historic Performances Recorded at the Monterey International Pop Festival")
featuring Redding and [Jimi Hendrix](/wiki/Jimi_Hendrix "Jimi Hendrix") at the
[Monterey Pop Festival](/wiki/Monterey_Pop_Festival "Monterey Pop Festival").
Both studio albums and anthologies sold well in [America](/wiki/United_States
"United States") and abroad. Redding was especially successful in the [United
Kingdom](/wiki/United_Kingdom "United Kingdom"), where _The Dock of the Bay_
went to number one, becoming the [first posthumous
album](/wiki/List_of_posthumous_number_ones_on_the_UK_Albums_Chart "List of
posthumous number ones on the UK Albums Chart") to reach the top spot
there.[32]

In 1999, [BMI](/wiki/Broadcast_Music,_Inc. "Broadcast Music, Inc.") named the
song as the sixth-most performed song of the twentieth century, with about six
million performances.[33] _[Rolling Stone](/wiki/Rolling_Stone "Rolling
Stone")_ ranked _The Dock of the Bay_ number 161 on its [500 Greatest Albums
of All Time](/wiki/Rolling_Stone%27s_500_Greatest_Albums_of_All_Time "Rolling
Stone's 500 Greatest Albums of All Time"), the third of five Redding albums on
the list. "(Sittin' On) The Dock of the Bay" was ranked twenty-eighth on
_[Rolling Stone](/wiki/Rolling_Stone "Rolling Stone")_ 's [500 Greatest Songs
of All Time](/wiki/500_Greatest_Songs_of_All_Time "500 Greatest Songs of All
Time"), the second-highest of four Redding songs on the list, after
"[Respect](/wiki/Respect_\(song\) "Respect \(song\)")".[34]

[Jim Morrison](/wiki/Jim_Morrison "Jim Morrison") made reference to "Dock of
the Bay" in the [Doors](/wiki/The_Doors "The Doors")' song "[Runnin'
Blue](/wiki/Runnin%27_Blue "Runnin' Blue")", written by Robby Krieger, from
their 1969 album _[The Soft Parade](/wiki/The_Soft_Parade "The Soft Parade")_.
Morrison sings an a capella intro for the song, singing directly about Otis
Redding. "Poor Otis dead and gone, left me here to sing his song, pretty
little girl with a red dress on, poor Otis dead and gone." And during the
verse, the lyrics "Got to find a dock and a bay" appear more than once; as
well as several other references to Redding's song.

#### Other cover
versions[[edit](/w/index.php?title=\(Sittin%27_On\)_The_Dock_of_the_Bay&action=edit&section=9
"Edit section: Other cover versions")]

In addition to the original Otis Redding version, several other versions have
charted on the [_Billboard_ Hot 100](/wiki/Billboard_Hot_100 "Billboard Hot
100") in the United States. [King Curtis](/wiki/King_Curtis "King Curtis")'s
version charted for five weeks starting in March 1968 and peaked at number 84
(during the same month, the original was number one). A year later, [Sergio
Mendes & Brasil '66](/wiki/Sergio_Mendes_%26_Brasil_%2766 "Sergio Mendes &
Brasil '66")'s version charted for five weeks starting in June 1969 and peaked
at number 66. [Sammy Hagar](/wiki/Sammy_Hagar "Sammy Hagar")'s version charted
for five weeks starting in April 1979, peaking at number 65. [The
Reddings](/wiki/The_Reddings "The Reddings"), who included two of Otis
Redding's sons, released a version which charted for nine weeks starting in
June 1982 and peaked at number 55. [Michael Bolton](/wiki/Michael_Bolton
"Michael Bolton")'s rendition charted for 17 weeks starting in January 1988
and peaked at number 11, making it the highest-charting cover version.[35]
